Presence of unusual or unexpected proces.Data: Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 5156
Presence of unusual or unexpected proces.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 for process creations. Cross-reference process names and paths against a baseline of known/allowed processes. Identify processes that have no prior history of network activity based on other available logs (e.g., Windows Event ID 5156, Zeek conn.log if applicable to the process type). Use correlation analysis to identify periods when unusual processes are created and network activity occurs.

Changes to host Bluetooth adapter settin.Data: Windows Event IDs related to device/driver changes
Changes to host Bluetooth adapter settin.Action: Monitor Windows System or Setup logs for Event IDs related to device/driver changes (e.g., Plug and Play events like Event ID 20001, driver installations). Look for events indicating the installation, connection, or modification of Bluetooth adapters or related drivers. Use time series analysis to identify spikes or anomalous patterns in adapter-related events across multiple hosts.

Use descriptive statistics on file sizes (if available or inferable) and types created in these directories to establish baselines and identify outliers.

System logs indicating Bluetooth radio o.Action: Monitor Windows System logs for Service Control Manager events (Event ID 7036 Service Control Manager) indicating the 'Bluetooth Support Service' changing to the running state, or 'Stopped' (Event ID 7035), particularly on machines where it is normally disabled or stopped. Correlate these events with suspicious file creation/modification (Windows Event ID 4663, 4688) or unusual process activity identified in other detections. Identify endpoints showing both suspicious data activity precursors and Bluetooth service activation around the same time using correlation analysis.
